title: All-China Women’s Federation donates electronic equipment to JNCW in 2005
description: On March 10, 2005, the Jordanian National Commission for Women (JNCW) received a donation of computer and electronic equipment from the All-China Women’s Federation. Throughout the ceremony, the JNCW expressed their gratitude towards the donation as it “fosters cooperation between national mechanisms” and will support the commission’s work. The specific contributions of the donation are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
All-China Women’s Federation donates electronic equipment to JNCW in 2005

# Description
On March 10, 2005, the Jordanian National Commission for Women (JNCW) received a donation of computer and electronic equipment from the All-China Women’s Federation. Throughout the ceremony, the JNCW expressed their gratitude towards the donation as it “fosters cooperation between national mechanisms” and will support the commission’s work. The specific contributions of the donation are unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of equipment to support women's organization activities, with no direct energy or environmental impact
evidence: Donation of computer and electronic equipment to support women's commission work, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Development Bank provides $218 million loan to KazNurTel LLP for the CDMA-450 Network Expansion Project
description: On July 4, 2005, China Development Bank signed a $218 million loan agreement with KazNurTel LLP -- a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of the Government of Kazakhstan (51% equity stake) and ZTE Corporation (49% equity stake) -- for a CDMA-450 (Code Division Multiple Access) Network Expansion Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  The project sought to provide trunking systems and internet access to rural areas in Kazakhstan. It also facilitated the sale of CDMA-450 telecommunications equipment and the provision of related technical support and after-sale services from Shenzhen Zhongxing Telecom Equipment Corporation (ZTE) to KazNurTel LLP.   KazNurTel LLP is a Chinese-Kazakh joint venture (special purpose vehicle) that was created for the manufacture of telecommunications equipment and provision of related services, in addition to the installation of CDMA networks.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Development Bank provides $218 million loan to KazNurTel LLP for the CDMA-450 Network Expansion Project

# Description
On July 4, 2005, China Development Bank signed a $218 million loan agreement with KazNurTel LLP -- a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of the Government of Kazakhstan (51% equity stake) and ZTE Corporation (49% equity stake) -- for a CDMA-450 (Code Division Multiple Access) Network Expansion Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  The project sought to provide trunking systems and internet access to rural areas in Kazakhstan. It also facilitated the sale of CDMA-450 telecommunications equipment and the provision of related technical support and after-sale services from Shenzhen Zhongxing Telecom Equipment Corporation (ZTE) to KazNurTel LLP.   KazNurTel LLP is a Chinese-Kazakh joint venture (special purpose vehicle) that was created for the manufacture of telecommunications equipment and provision of related services, in addition to the installation of CDMA networks.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure expansion without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: CDMA-450 network expansion, rural internet access, telecommunications equipment provision

title: China completes Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University
description: In July 2005, the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev when meeting with Chairman Hu Jintao proposed intentions to establish Confucius Institute in Kazakhstan. On December 20, 2006, Hanban and Eurasian national university from Kazakhstan signed a cooperation agreement to establish a Confucius Institute with Xi'an International Studies University become Chinese side’s executive body. In August 2007, Xi'an International Studies University and Eurasian National University signed "Implementation Agreement" of cooperation in the establishment of Confucius Institute and set up a board of directors of Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University. December 5th, 2007, Confucius Institute at the Eurasian National University held the opening ceremony. Minister of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan Zhanseit Tuimebayev, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the People’s Republic of China in Kazakhstan Zhang Xiyun and representatives of the governments of Kazakhstan and China attended opening ceremony and made a speech. Tuimebaev said, with becoming closer in the political, economic, cultural and other areas of cooperation with China, Kazakhstan will need more and more well-trained Chinese language personnel. Confucius Institute established in Kazakhstan will make a great contribution promoting bilateral cooperation in various fields.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China completes Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University

# Description
In July 2005, the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev when meeting with Chairman Hu Jintao proposed intentions to establish Confucius Institute in Kazakhstan. On December 20, 2006, Hanban and Eurasian national university from Kazakhstan signed a cooperation agreement to establish a Confucius Institute with Xi'an International Studies University become Chinese side’s executive body. In August 2007, Xi'an International Studies University and Eurasian National University signed "Implementation Agreement" of cooperation in the establishment of Confucius Institute and set up a board of directors of Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University. December 5th, 2007, Confucius Institute at the Eurasian National University held the opening ceremony. Minister of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan Zhanseit Tuimebayev, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the People’s Republic of China in Kazakhstan Zhang Xiyun and representatives of the governments of Kazakhstan and China attended opening ceremony and made a speech. Tuimebaev said, with becoming closer in the political, economic, cultural and other areas of cooperation with China, Kazakhstan will need more and more well-trained Chinese language personnel. Confucius Institute established in Kazakhstan will make a great contribution promoting bilateral cooperation in various fields.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for Chinese language education and cultural cooperation

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $63,700 USD for newspaper and magazine subscriptions for World War II veterans (Linked to Project ID#73474)
description: On May 9, 2003, Victory Day, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, set aside $63,700 USD to subscribe Kazakhstani veterans of World War II to newspapers and magazines. CNPC AMG was still spending that amount every year as of 2017. This project captures CNPC's purchase of subscriptions in 2005.  Linked project ID#73474 is the umbrella project for the newspaper and magazines subscriptions. Below is a list of projects that capture the money set aside for the subscriptions for every year from 2003 to 2017.  - 2003: Project ID#73487 - 2004: Project ID#73488 - 2005: Project ID#73489 - 2006: Project ID#73490 - 2007: Project ID#73491 - 2008: Project ID#73492 - 2009: Project ID#73493 - 2010: Project ID#73494 - 2011: Project ID#73495 - 2012: Project ID#73496 - 2013: Project ID#73497 - 2014: Project ID#73498 - 2015: Project ID#73499 - 2016: Project ID#73500 - 2017: Project ID#73501
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $63,700 USD for newspaper and magazine subscriptions for World War II veterans (Linked to Project ID#73474)

# Description
On May 9, 2003, Victory Day, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, set aside $63,700 USD to subscribe Kazakhstani veterans of World War II to newspapers and magazines. CNPC AMG was still spending that amount every year as of 2017. This project captures CNPC's purchase of subscriptions in 2005.  Linked project ID#73474 is the umbrella project for the newspaper and magazines subscriptions. Below is a list of projects that capture the money set aside for the subscriptions for every year from 2003 to 2017.  - 2003: Project ID#73487 - 2004: Project ID#73488 - 2005: Project ID#73489 - 2006: Project ID#73490 - 2007: Project ID#73491 - 2008: Project ID#73492 - 2009: Project ID#73493 - 2010: Project ID#73494 - 2011: Project ID#73495 - 2012: Project ID#73496 - 2013: Project ID#73497 - 2014: Project ID#73498 - 2015: Project ID#73499 - 2016: Project ID#73500 - 2017: Project ID#73501
justification: Project is focused on providing social benefits to veterans without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Newspaper and magazine subscriptions for World War II veterans, social welfare focus

title: CDB contributes $1.08 billion to $4.18 billion syndicated loan for acquisition of PetroKazakhstan Inc.
description: On August 22, 2005, PetroKazakhstan Inc. (PKZ) announced that it had entered into an Arrangement Agreement whereby a wholly-owned subsidiary of CNPC International Limited (CNPCI) would offer $55.00 per share in cash for all outstanding common shares of PetroKazakhstan. The aggregate value of this transaction was approximately $4.18 billion. The offer represented a premium of 24.4% based on the weighted average closing price of PetroKazakhstan common shares on the New York Stock Exchange for the twenty previous trading days ending August 19, 2005 and a 21.1% premium to the closing price on August 19, 2005, the most recent date on which the shares traded.   Then, in September 2005, CNPC International Limited secured a $4.18 billion (€3.4 billion) bridge loan from a syndicate consisting of 3 banks — Citigroup, Sanpaolo IM (now part of Intesa Sanpaolo), and China Development Bank (CDB) — to facilitate the acquisition of PetroKazakhstan Inc. It is known that Citigroup contributed $2.1 billion and Sanpaolo IM contributed $1 billion to the syndicated loan. Therefore, AidData assumes that CDB contributed the remaining $1.08 billion. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.   Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil, asked an Alberta court to hold up the sale while it sought a ruling on whether it should have the first opportunity to buy an oil field that it and PetroKazakstan Inc. co-owned. However, Justice Neil Wittmann of the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench approved the sale in October 2005.  The Kazakh Parliament also objected to the sale of PetroKazakhstan Inc. to CNPC. Those objections were overcome, however, when CNPC agreed to sell a 33% equity interest in PetroKazakhstan Inc. to KazMunaiGas NC JSC  (a Kazakh national oil company). Then, in August 2006, CNPC E&D entered into an acquisition agreement to acquire a 67% equity interest in PetroKazakhstan Inc. from CNPCI for a consideration of $2.735 billion. This acquisition was consummated in December 2006.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 哈萨克斯坦PK收购 or 中石油收购哈萨克斯坦PK 公司. 2. PetroKazakhstan Inc. is a vertically integrated, international energy company, in the Republic of Kazakhstan. It is engaged in the acquisition, exploration, development and production of oil and gas, refining of oil and the sale of oil and refined products. CNPC International Ltd. ('CNPCI') is wholly owned by China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). CNPC E&D is a joint venture equally owned by PetroChina and China National Oil & Gas Exploration and Development Corporation, subsidiaries of CNPC. 3. On October 18, 2005 the Alberta Province Court (Canada) postponed a transaction approval of PKZ assets acquisition by CNPC until October 26, 2005 in accordance with LUKOIL's claim concerning its preemption right recognition to purchase a share in Turgai Petroleum – a joint venture of LUKOIL and PKZ.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CDB contributes $1.08 billion to $4.18 billion syndicated loan for acquisition of PetroKazakhstan Inc.

# Description
On August 22, 2005, PetroKazakhstan Inc. (PKZ) announced that it had entered into an Arrangement Agreement whereby a wholly-owned subsidiary of CNPC International Limited (CNPCI) would offer $55.00 per share in cash for all outstanding common shares of PetroKazakhstan. The aggregate value of this transaction was approximately $4.18 billion. The offer represented a premium of 24.4% based on the weighted average closing price of PetroKazakhstan common shares on the New York Stock Exchange for the twenty previous trading days ending August 19, 2005 and a 21.1% premium to the closing price on August 19, 2005, the most recent date on which the shares traded.   Then, in September 2005, CNPC International Limited secured a $4.18 billion (€3.4 billion) bridge loan from a syndicate consisting of 3 banks — Citigroup, Sanpaolo IM (now part of Intesa Sanpaolo), and China Development Bank (CDB) — to facilitate the acquisition of PetroKazakhstan Inc. It is known that Citigroup contributed $2.1 billion and Sanpaolo IM contributed $1 billion to the syndicated loan. Therefore, AidData assumes that CDB contributed the remaining $1.08 billion. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.   Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil, asked an Alberta court to hold up the sale while it sought a ruling on whether it should have the first opportunity to buy an oil field that it and PetroKazakstan Inc. co-owned. However, Justice Neil Wittmann of the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench approved the sale in October 2005.  The Kazakh Parliament also objected to the sale of PetroKazakhstan Inc. to CNPC. Those objections were overcome, however, when CNPC agreed to sell a 33% equity interest in PetroKazakhstan Inc. to KazMunaiGas NC JSC  (a Kazakh national oil company). Then, in August 2006, CNPC E&D entered into an acquisition agreement to acquire a 67% equity interest in PetroKazakhstan Inc. from CNPCI for a consideration of $2.735 billion. This acquisition was consummated in December 2006.
justification: The project involves the acquisition of an oil company, which directly supports fossil fuel extraction and production
evidence: Acquisition of PetroKazakhstan Inc., an oil company, by CNPC International Limited

title: ZTE donates donates communications equipment for Telkom Kenya
description: Guo Chong Li, the Chinese ambassador to Kenya, reports that the Chinese telecom firm ZTE Communications donated Sh144 million worth of communication equipment to Telkom Kenya. The purpose of the donation goes to improve the quality of telecommunication in Kenya.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
ZTE donates donates communications equipment for Telkom Kenya

# Description
Guo Chong Li, the Chinese ambassador to Kenya, reports that the Chinese telecom firm ZTE Communications donated Sh144 million worth of communication equipment to Telkom Kenya. The purpose of the donation goes to improve the quality of telecommunication in Kenya.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications equipment donation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of communication equipment to improve telecommunication quality

title: China's Central Television donated TV equipment for Kenya Broadcasting Corporation
description: On January 25, 2005, China's Central Television [CCTV] donated TV equipment worth 12 million KES to Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC). The state-of-the-art equipment, including nonlinear editing system, digital video recorder and monitor, were handed over through the Chinese embassy in Nairobi. Wachira Waruru, Managing Director of the KBC, received the equipment from Guo Chongli, Chinese Ambassador to Kenya.
combined_text:
# Sector

China's Central Television donated TV equipment for Kenya Broadcasting Corporation

# Description

The state-of-the-art equipment, including nonlinear editing system, digital video recorder and monitor, were handed over through the Chinese embassy in Nairobi. Wachira Waruru, Managing Director of the KBC, received the equipment from Guo Chongli, Chinese Ambassador to Kenya.
justification: Project involves donation of broadcasting equipment for media development, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of TV equipment to Kenya Broadcasting Corporation, focus on media infrastructure development

title: China establishes Radio Station to promote Chinese culture in Kenya
description: In November 2005, China announced that it would set up an FM radio station in Nairobi, Kenya. The station would promote Chinese culture. On February 27, 2006, Wang Gengnian, director-general of China Radio International, and Mutahi Kagwe, Kenyan Minister of Information and Communications, launched the China Radio International station 91.9FM in Nairobi. The amount and start date are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China establishes Radio Station to promote Chinese culture in Kenya

# Description
In November 2005, China announced that it would set up an FM radio station in Nairobi, Kenya. The station would promote Chinese culture. On February 27, 2006, Wang Gengnian, director-general of China Radio International, and Mutahi Kagwe, Kenyan Minister of Information and Communications, launched the China Radio International station 91.9FM in Nairobi. The amount and start date are unknown.
justification: Project focuses on cultural promotion and media infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of FM radio station for cultural promotion, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China opens Confucius Institute at the University of Nairobi, linked to #59699
description: The Confucius Institute at the University of Nairobi was founded on June 22 2004 by the University of Nairobi in Kenya and Chinese Institution Tianjin Normal University. This is the first Confucius Institute in Kenya, opening on 19 Dec 2005 at the address: University of Nairobi Main Campus P. O. Box 30197-00100 Nairobi, Kenya. It is unclear how the institute is funded. Person of contact: Isaac Mbeche GUO Hong(郭红), Tel: +254-736701640, E-mail: isambeche@yahoo.com; bjlcn@126.com, Website: http://www.uonbi.ac.ke/. The institute was renovated with a Chinese grant in 2014, see #59699.
